docs.lead_paragraph: Fertility treatments to help couples conceive should be covered by medical insurance in New York State, the Speaker of the State Assembly proposed yesterday. Infertility ''tears apart lives, marriages and families,'' Speaker Sheldon Silver said.

headline.main: Speaker Urges Coverage For Fertility Treatments

docs.abstract: New York State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver says that fertility treatments to help couples conceive should be covered by medical insurance in New York State (S)
docs.snippet: Fertility treatments to help couples conceive should be covered by medical insurance in New York State, the Speaker of the State Assembly proposed yesterday.    Infertility ''tears apart lives, marriages and families,'' Speaker Sheldon Silver said.

docs.lead_paragraph: At Intermediate School 218 in Washington Heights, 12-year-old Billy W. Vargas had severe chest pains one morning during class and could not catch his breath. He was having an asthma attack, a nurse determined. Another student, Eddy Peralta, 14, was having difficulty concentrating in class because he kept having severe headaches and getting dizzy. As it turned out, he needed new glasses.

headline.main: Reading, Writing and Runny Noses; For Those Without Insurance, School Health Clinics Fill In

docs.abstract: Article on New York City school-based health clinics increasingly becoming primary source of health care for children of families without health insurance; there are currently 158 centers in some of most impoverished neighborhoods throughout New York State, 110 of them in New York City; some of clinics are financed by state, others by city and some are set up by not-for-profit organizations; almost all are affiliated with large hospitals or comprehensive neighborhood health centers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton made a campaign-style trip yesterday into the heart of the Long Island suburbs that would be crucial to winning a race for United States Senate, then came back into Manhattan for two more events to finish off a 13-hour day. But in a total of six appearances before such Democratic constituencies as teachers, lawyers, women, Jews, members of minority groups and patrons of the arts, Mrs. Clinton made no teasing references to her potential Senate race, as she has in the past, and stayed within the bounds of First Lady.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton makes campaign-style trip into heart of Long Island suburbs that would be crucial to winning race for United States Senate, then comes back into Manhattan for two more events to finish off 13-hour day; does not mention possible candidacy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats in Congress kicked off a major effort today to secure Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, one of the biggest expenses for millions of elderly people. The fight for such benefits promises to continue into next year's elections, as candidates from both parties search for ways to plug a conspicuous hole in Medicare coverage and try to solve the program's long-term financial problems.

headline.main: Democrats Seeking Medicare Coverage for Prescription Drugs

docs.abstract: Democrats in Congress open major effort to win Medicare coverage of prescription drugs; Sen Edward M Kennedy offers Democratic proposal under which Medicare would pay 80 percent of drug costs, after beneficiaries pay $200 deductible; would cap cost to beneficiaries at $3000 a year; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Democrats in Congress kicked off a major effort today to secure Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, one of the biggest expenses for millions of elderly people.    The fight for such benefits promises to continue into next year's elections, as...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am disgusted with the lenience of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn in sentencing Rabbi Hertz Frankel to three years' probation for essentially embezzling $6 million in public money (news articles, April 16 and 17). You call it siphoning, but what Rabbi Frankel did was steal.
docs.abstract: Reid Armbruster letter deplores lenient sentence given to Rabbi Hertz Frankel, three years' probation for essentially embezzling $6 million in public money; contends Frankel is getting away with slap on the wrist, just because he is a religious figure

docs.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of New York City's public hospital system said yesterday that North Central Bronx Hospital, with 1,200 unionized health care workers and room for 450 beds, would almost certainly close in the next two to three years because of a steady decline in the number of patients it treats. Over the last several months, the hospital has already scaled back considerably. It has closed its pediatrics ward and reduced the number of patients in its medical wards from 90 to 60, according to letters from the hospital's administrators.

headline.main: Closing Is Seen for Hospital in 2 to 3 Years

docs.abstract: Health and Hospitals Corp pres Dr Luis R Marcos says that North Central Bronx Hospital, with 1,200 unionized health care workers and room for 450 beds, will almost certainly close in next two to three years because of steady decline in number of patients it treats (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ROBERT C. ATKINS is the best-selling author of ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution,'' published in 1972 and the first of what has become an industry of diet books. He is also the engineer of a weight-loss method known universally as ''the Atkins Diet.'' Yet he doesn't want to be called a diet doc, and says that helping people slim down is a small part of his daily work. What Dr. Atkins' daily work does involve is running a holistic healing center on Fifth Avenue, hosting a live weekday radio show, lobbying to promote alternative medicine and turning out a new book every couple of years. The latest, ''Dr. Atkins' Vita Nutrient Solution,'' a guide to vitamin and herbal therapies used in the physician's practice, is written with as much staunch confidence as its predecessors.

headline.main: On Island, Books of Individualism; Doctor With a Diet Has a New Message

docs.abstract: Robert Atkins, best-selling author of diet books, comments on his latest, Dr Atkins' Vita-Nutrient Solution, guide to vitamin and herbal therapies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Private Hospital Rooms No Longer a Luxury Many new hospitals offer private rooms for all patients, thanks to changes in insurance, competition for business, and concern over patients' health. Page 20. Efforts at Air Purity
docs.snippet: Private Hospital Rooms No Longer a Luxury    Many new hospitals offer private rooms for all patients, thanks to changes in insurance, competition for business, and concern over patients' health. Page 20.    Efforts at Air Purity

docs.lead_paragraph: ''WE need bodies,'' said Paul Elwell, chief of the Roxbury volunteer fire department. ''We haven't had a new recruit in a year. Half of our firefighters are in their 50's and 60's.'' In Morris, a nearby town also in Litchfield County, the volunteer fire chief, Lewis Clark, said he had trouble rounding up enough daytime volunteers to answer recent fire and ambulance calls. ''I'm burned out,'' he said, ''in more ways than one.''

headline.main: Who Will Answer the Call? Search Goes On for Volunteers

docs.abstract: Article describes problems many volunteer fire departments in Connecticut face in recruiting and retaining members (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CAROLE COTLER had been taking her dog, Berklee, to long-term care facilities and nursing homes all over Long Island. She had seen how her friendly bulldog-boxer mix brightened the days and lifted the spirits of the sick and the aged, and had read about the patients jarred from comas and the catatonics smiling for the first time when exposed to the increasingly popular discipline known as animal-assisted therapy. Ms. Cotler was sure that Berklee's affections would work equally well in hospitals. But the state Health Department barred animals from hospitals. Then a year ago, the state revamped its rules to allow animal-assisted therapy programs into acute-care facilities. Since the regulation was amended, teams of certified dogs and their owners are being courted by the rehabilitation, geriatric and pediatric units of hospitals throughout the Island as even the most conservative hospital administrators are convinced that dogs can help spark remarkable improvement in many patients' lives.

headline.main: When Command is 'Heal,' These Dogs Obey

docs.abstract: Article on popularity of pet therapy sessions involving dogs at hospital rehabilitation, geriatric and pediatric units throughout Long Island in year since New York revamped rule barring animals from hospitals; photos (M)
